They're scrambling, you know, doing small repairs, you know, various small repairs that a few years ago, you know, people would have put off or sold their house instead of doing the repairs.
But the sad fact is, when you're building only four homes a year, you can't hire everyone that needs work.
One of his favorite contractors is Jerry Sable(ph).
Portelli's known him for years and says he is one of the best in Michigan.
We didn't see the mortgage crisis coming.
Sable is standing in front of a shell of a home with no doors or walls.
There are about 20 feet of bricks stacked in front of it, covered with snow.
This house has been here for about four months, at least.
And it's unsold and it's just unfinished.
Just unfinished.
unfinished.
And you have to leave it that way because, number one, the builder doesn't want to put in any more money in it.
And I don't blame him.
And if you put in more mechanicals, they're subject to damage and stuff, so you just leave it and protect it as best you can.
Sable says another developer in Pontiac, Michigan built a model unit and kept it open for six months without selling a single house.
That project has been scrapped.
Our business is down 75-80 percent.
We had 28 people working four weeks, sometimes a lot of overtime.
And now we're down to six or eight.
And we're - it's very difficult to stay alive these days in business.
Last month, housing stocks fell to the lowest level since 1991.
Building permits that are often used as a predictor of future construction are down 34 percent for single-family homes.
On an emotional point of view, it's very trying.
People have worked for us for many years.
And some of them just right out of high school and worked for us, got married, have a couple of kids.
And now - and I have to lay them off.
And I'm more worried about the people that worked for me than myself.
We'll be fine personally.
As for Frank Portelli, he has no employees and he doesn't build a house unless it's paid for.
He says he survived only because he has adapted.
Whereas before, I was involved in, you know, quality control, training of superintendents, selecting contractors.
Now, as an independent, you know, I had become a Web master.
I am also the banker.
I'm also the sales person.
I'm also - a lot of different hats that I didn't have to wear before, I just assumed somebody else on my team was taking care of it.
Now, I do all those things myself.
Portelli says he thinks the new construction industry will be radically changed by the mortgage crisis.
And all builders who have to adapt or find new industries.
For NPR News, I'm Celeste Headlee in Detroit.
From the studios of NPR West, this is DAY TO DAY.
I'm Madeleine Brand.
I'm Alex Chadwick.
Coming up, Santa helper stories.
Two men try to play the role and get very different results.
First, a federal judge has completed his hearing in the case of the CIA interrogation tapes.
These are videos that the CIA destroyed of the harsh questioning and possibly torture of a terror suspect.
The suspect in this case is a Palestinian named Abu Zubaydah.
And there's another development in his story today.
The McClatchy newspapers are reporting that the Department of Justice is investigating a former CIA agent who talked to reporters about the capture and interrogation of this suspect.
The story is by Jonathan Landay in the McClatchy Washington Bureau.
Jonathan, welcome to DAY TO DAY.
And what have you learned in this story?

What I learned was that the Department of Justice has opened a criminal investigation into Mr. Kiriakou to determine whether or not in giving all of the interviews that he gave, whether he disclosed classified information, which is indeed against the law.
Now, this is John Kiriakou.
He is this former CIA agent I mentioned earlier.
What is his story and why was he talking to so many people last week, including NPR?

He appears to have been part of a CIA operational unit that was in on the raid in which this man, Abu Zubaydah, was captured in March 2002, and was apparently the first CIA officer to spend time talking with Mr. Zubaydah, who was severely wounded when he was captured.
But apparently Mr. Kiriakou did not spend that much time speaking with Mr. Zubaydah.
In fact, I'm told he spent very little time and then went back to the United States, where he kept abreast of the interrogation of Mr. Zubaydah through documents.

Apparently he decided to go public talking about the interrogation and the use this procedure known as waterboarding on Mr. Zubaydah because he had come to believe that the procedure constituted torture, although he says at the time he believed it was necessary to avert new plots against the United States.

So what's the response from the Justice Department and the CIA to this story that they are investigating a source for the story about this - the waterboarding techniques and the CIA's destruction of these videotapes?
What happens is, it's rather routine for the CIA to send to the Justice Department what are known as criminal referrals when there are disclosures of classified information.
And that is indeed what I'm told happened in this case.
Now, the fact is that publicly the CIA and the Justice Department won't speak about criminal referrals because they are not public business.
At the same time, the director of the CIA, General Michael Hayden, has been quite clear since he took over the CIA that he was going to take a hard line on any leaks of classified information.
All right.
Well, Mr. Kiriakou, as I said, was interviewed by a number of news organizations last week, including NPR.
Here he is speaking with Robert Siegel from ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
To this my knowledge there's no hard and fast rule on speaking so long as you don't reveal sources and methods or classified information.
And I believe firmly that I have not revealed classified information or sources and methods.
There's a subway four blocks from the house--four or five--no more than six blocks.
